Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: US-KU-QA-AE Planning Visit - The Impact of American Higher Education in the Gulf Arab States
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CNIC project supports a planning visit to three countries in the Arabian Gulf by two US Investigators, Dr. Natalie Koch of Syracuse University in New York and Dr. Neha Vora of Lafayette College in Pennsylvania. Their planning visit will help develop a multi-year project that explores the impacts of American-style universities in three key monarchies in the Arab Gulf: Kuwait, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates (UAE), engaging local partners at the University of Kuwait, Texas A&M University-Qatar, and the American University of Sharjah in the UAE.

Over the last two decades, most states of the GCC (Gulf Cooperative Council) have established programs to move away from petroleum reliance through the development of "knowledge-based" economies. These countries are investing heavily in higher education, and have deliberately chosen to adopt US models of higher education, encouraging the establishment of branch campuses of top American universities, seeking out US university partnerships, and even restructured national universities to include American-style mission statements, student citizenship models and curricular offerings. Adopting a three-country comparative approach, the investigators will use targeted case studies and draw upon the complementary insights of their two disciplines, cultural anthropology and political geography, to explore how key actors negotiate different Gulf and American value systems in developing and administering pedagogy (faculty and administrators) and in the classroom and postgraduate careers (students). This CNIC grant will enable the PIs and their local collaborators to design a mixed-methods project to be submitted to the NSF core programs in Cultural Anthropology and Geography and Spatial Sciences. This CNIC project will help develop a valuable collaboration between American and Gulf-based scholars to evaluate how the ostensibly conflicting value systems between liberal education and non-liberal nationalization policies operate on the ground and assessing the impact of recent higher education transformations on Gulf countries. Their results will help inform academic and policy debates in the U.S. regarding the development of branch campuses and many other types of collaborations in the region.

There has been minimal ethnographic research to date on the impacts US-modeled institutions are having in their host countries beyond the campus walls. The study resulting from this planning visit grant will develop a more nuanced understanding of the broader impacts of American higher education in the Gulf Arab states in terms of citizenship practices, gender roles, and post-oil economic futures. The findings promise to be highly relevant to U.S. policy-makers and U.S. university administrators, as they navigate the politics and economics of developing international branch campuses and foreign university partnerships. In addition to laying the groundwork for an innovative empirical and theoretical research agenda and promoting the early-career development of the PIs, this planning grant will help develop a highly relevant practical agenda that can speak to a broad audience within both academic and policy circles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a “Catalyzing New International Collaborations” (CNIC) seed grant, this project’s goal was to generate collaborative opportunities between American and Gulf Cooperative Council (GCC)-based scholars, with particular attention to research that engages STEM field growth and transformation in the Gulf states. Two US based scholars—one an anthropologist and one a geographer—who both have research expertise in the Gulf region and an interest in the burgeoning higher education there connected with scholars and administrators within American and American-style universities in Kuwait, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates in order to develop a dialogue about the shape and design of an interdisciplinary, comparative, and collaborative study on the impact of American education on knowledge economy development in the GCC. The project’s primary goal was to help the PIs initiate this academic network, while also familiarizing themselves more thoroughly with educational reform and the range of American higher education models in the target countries, in preparation for a larger follow-on study, currently being prepared for submission to the NSF in August 2016.

 

In the framework of this grant, the PIs traveled to the Middle East two times each, for a combined 9 weeks of international research. The PIs traveled together for portions of this research, and also independently, in order to maximize the number of institutions reached and to keep up a sustained dialog with scholars and universities that best fit within the scope of the larger project. These included visits to various sites in Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates in order to visit potential partner institutions and to meet with current and potential collaborators for the planned follow-on study. There they toured campuses and met with scholars, deans, and research officers at various institutions. Both PIs had planning meetings with individuals at American University of Kuwait; American University of Sharjah (UAE); American University of Ras al Khaimah (UAE); Texas A&M-Qatar; Georgetown University-Qatar; and Qatar Community College. In addition to these, PI Vora met with potential collaborators from the Sheikh Saud bin Saqr Al Qasimi Foundation for Policy Research (UAE), Dubai School of Government (UAE), Qatar University, and Carnegie Mellon University Qatar. And, PI Koch also visited Gulf University for Science and Technology in Kuwait; New York University-Abu Dhabi (UAE); Virginia Commonwealth University in Qatar; and Northwestern University-Qatar. During preliminary and follow-up meetings, the PIs discussed research questions for the planned larger study, which would engage both the US and Gulf-based collaborators, as well as logistics such as timing, funding, staffing, and data management issues.

 

As a seed grant, this project was primarily focused on providing opportunities for the PIs, both early career faculty members, to develop and extend their academic networks in the Gulf countries. The grant enabled them to advance these working relationships through in-country planning meetings, and to explore exciting new directions in their research on higher education, nation-building and modernization, and citizenship and nondemocratic polities in the GCC states. It allowed the PIs practical experience in working together in the field, as well as in the logistical hurdles of developing and implementing a multi-country interdisciplinary and collaborative project, which will prove essential for their future career success given the international nature of their disciplines (anthropology and geography) and their individual research interests.


Last Modified: 02/26/2016
Modified by: Neha Vora
